results.title: Danger! Radio active waste
results.creator_credit: Joan Konner, NBC News and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: Progress is in a dead heat with destruction as the nuclear industry tries to keep ahead of its own waste, all of which is radioactive and therefore highly dangerous. The horrors of radioactive overexposure - possible genetic damage, increased incidences of cancer and leukemia, and others, are further heightened by an apparent inability of both government and industry to solve the nuclear waste disposal problem.

results.title: Hang onto yourself: no fun
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
In ‘Hang onto yourself’, this episode features an in-depth look at the many faces of David Bowie, particularly as the glam phenomena Ziggy Stardust. The rise of performers such as Alice Cooper, Lou Reed and Ziggy is seen as a response to the hangover from the summer of love where rock developed theatricality. The rise of Reggae and Punk music is the subject of the episode entitled ‘No fun’ and features clips and interviews with pivotal figures such as Malcolm McClaren, The Sex Pistols, Bob Marley and Talking Heads.

results.title: Make it funky. Planet rock.
results.creator_credit: Don Letts, Yvonne Smith, Hugh Thompson, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
Afro-american musicians developed their own unique style which celebrated their rich cultural heritage. The episode ‘Make it funky’ features interviews and perfomances by such legends as James Brown, Sly and the Family Stone, Stevie Wonder and Marvin Gaye. The final episode in the series ‘Planet rock’ looks at rap, hip-hop and techno and the use of computers as musical instruments which allow music to become an instant global experience. Features interviews and clips from New Order, The Beastie Boys and Public Enemy.

results.title: Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Hugh Thompson, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description: An outstanding documentary series examining the history of rock and roll which contains in-depth interviews with pivotal figures in rock and roll history and rare footage of performances by legendary artists. The research and in-depth analysis make this worth watching.

results.title: Crossroads. Eight miles high
results.creator_credit: Mick Conefrey, Alan Lewens, Karen Walsh, High Thomson, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
The Blues crosses the Atlantic and reaches Britain where it finds a new direction. Groups like the Beatles and the Rolling Stones invade America and somewhere in the process Heavy Metal is invented. In this episode entitled ‘Crossroads’, interviews and performances by legendary musicians such as The Rolling Stones, Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck are featured. In the second program ‘Eight miles high’ the whole phenomenon of Psychadelia is explored, including interviews and clips from The Grateful Dead, Janis Joplin and Pink Floyd. This episode captures a landmark era in the development of rock music in the 1960’s.

results.title: Whole lotta shaking: R.E.S.P.E.C.T.
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Hugh Thompson, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
Whole lotta shakin examines the grass roots beginnings of rock and roll. In New Orleans, Afro-american performers like Little Richard were unleashing a new type of music which echoed through the Mississippi Delta into Sam Phillips’ Studio in Memphis. What was predominantly Afro-american music became “legitimised” commercially when singers like Elvis Presley emulated this energetic form of music. “R.E.S.P.E.C.T”: Motown and Stax records paved the way for legendary Afro-american singers to become successful in their own right. Aretha Franklin was the Queen of Soul, but artists like Ray Charles, Martha Reeves, Otis Redding and the Supremes also made their mark as rock and roll legends.

results.title: Dances with wolves [Portuguese subtitles]
results.creator_credit: Kevin Costner, Jim Wilson, Majestic Films International and TIG Productions
results.brief_description: Assigned to an abandoned army post, Civil War hero John Dunbar (Kevin Costner), finds himself alone and beyond civilisation. Only a wolf and some roving Sioux Indians provide distractions. Curiosity and survival force Dunbar to overcome his fear and he develops a unique relationship with the Sioux. But as the US military ruthlessly pushes west, the Indians’ existence is threatened and Dunbar finds himself torn between two cultures. Honoured with seven Academy Awards including Best Picture (1991), this epic is a cinematic masterpiece of scope, beauty, spirituality and rousing adventure. Dean Semler’s photography is breathtaking. Screenplay by Michael Blake, based on his novel. In English with Portugese subtitles.

results.title: Dancers
results.creator_credit: Herbert Ross, Yoram Globus, Menahem Golan, Baryshnikov Productions, Hera Productions and Golan-Globus
results.brief_description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, one of the world’s greatest and most admired ballet dancers stars in this romantic drama about an American ballet company’s arrival in Italy to perform the romantic ballet ‘Giselle’. Baryshnikov plays Tony (Anton) Sergeyev, lead dancer and director of the production, ladies’ man, experienced and charming who finds himself attracted to the newest member of his troupe, the young and naive American teenager Lisa (Julie Kent). Art begins to mirror life as the drama of love and betrayal of ‘Giselle’ is played out backstage between Tony and Lisa. Features the dancers of the American Ballet Theater, Allesandra Ferri (Francesca), Leslie Browne (Nadine) and Mariangela Melato (the Contessa). ‘Giselle’ is conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas and performed by the London Symphony Orchestra, original music by Pino Donaggio.

results.title: Dandenong South Public Art Project
results.creator_credit: Renata Slusarski, Michael Blunden and Mal Padgett
results.brief_description: In 2004 a collaboration between the City of Greater Dandenong, Big Fish (a design and construction team), and the community of Dandenong South was formed to create a permanent, highly visible sculpture representing the cultural diversity of Dandenong South. Children from the Dandenong South Primary School were given disposable cameras and asked to take photos of the things that were culturally important to them and their favourite places in Dandenong South. Conversations with the local school children, community leaders, local identities and workers in Dandenong South were recorded on film and it was from both the children’s images and the different perspectives captured in the film that ultimately combined to provide the inspiration and design for the artists’ symbolic community artwork.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Renata Slusarski, Michael Blunden and Mal Padgett
